title: Networking Quiz
description: Quiz covering networking fundamentals and applications.

questions.text: Which protocol operates on TCP port 22?
questions.explanation: SSH (Secure Shell) operates on TCP port 22 and is used for secure logins, file transfers, and port forwarding.

questions.text: What is the purpose of ARP?
questions.explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) maps IP addresses to MAC addresses.
correctAnswers: Maps IP addresses to MAC addresses
wrongAnswers: Maps MAC addresses to IP addresses

questions.text: UDP is a connection-oriented protocol.
questions.explanation: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is a connectionless protocol, while TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is connection-oriented.

questions.text: Which of the following is a private IP address range?
questions.explanation: 192.168.0.0/16 is a private IP address range.

questions.text: What is the function of a router?
questions.explanation: Routers interconnect LANs and WANs and determine the next network to which an address is sent.
wrongAnswers: Filter network traffic based on MAC addresses
Convert analog signals to digital signals

questions.text: The OSI model has 5 layers.
questions.explanation: The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model has 7 layers.

questions.text: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for encryption and decryption?
questions.explanation: The Presentation layer (Layer 6) of the OSI model is responsible for encryption and decryption.

questions.text: What is the purpose of DHCP?
questions.explanation: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) grants IP addresses to connected devices in a network.
correctAnswers: Grants IP addresses to connected devices
wrongAnswers: Translates domain names to IP addresses

questions.text: Which command is used to display active TCP connections on a Windows system?
questions.explanation: netstat is used to display active TCP connections, ports on which the computer is listening.

questions.text: A firewall is a network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic.
questions.explanation: A firewall is a network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.

questions.text: What is the default TTL value for packets originating from a Windows system?
questions.explanation: The default TTL (Time-to-Live) value for packets originating from a Windows system is 128.

questions.text: Which protocol is used for sending emails?
questions.explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is used to send mail messages across a network and is the basis for internet mail.

questions.text: NAT translates private IP addresses to different public IP addresses.
questions.explanation: NAT (Network Address Translation) translates private IP addresses to one or multiple routable IP addresses. PAT translates private to same public IP address, different port.

questions.text: What is the port number for DNS?
questions.explanation: DNS (Domain Name Service) primarily uses UDP port 53, but TCP is used when packets are larger.

questions.text: Which of the following is a distance-vector routing protocol?
questions.explanation: RIP (Routing Information Protocol) is one of the oldest distance-vector routing protocols.

questions.text: A MAC address operates at the Network Layer (Layer 3) of the OSI model.
questions.explanation: MAC addresses operate at the Data Link Layer (Layer 2) of the OSI model.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the TCP/IP 3-way handshake?
questions.explanation: The TCP/IP 3-way handshake is used to establish a connection between a client and a server.
correctAnswers: Establish a connection between a client and a server
wrongAnswers: Terminate a connection between a client and a server
Resolve IP addresses to MAC addresses

questions.text: Which IEEE standard defines Ethernet?
questions.explanation: IEEE 802.3 defines Ethernet.

questions.text: A hub sends signals to a specific port based on MAC addresses.
questions.explanation: Switches send signals to specific ports based on MAC addresses, while hubs broadcast signals to all connected ports.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the 'traceroute' command?
questions.explanation: The traceroute command prints the route packets trace to network host.
correctAnswers: Print the route packets trace to network host
wrongAnswers: Resolve domain names to IP addresses

questions.text: Which IPv6 address type is equivalent to IPv4's private address ranges?
questions.explanation: Unique Local Addresses (ULA) in IPv6 are similar in scope to IPv4 private addresses, providing addressing within a site.

questions.text: What is the IPv6 equivalent of IPv4's APIPA (Automatic Private IP Addressing)?
questions.explanation: IPv6 uses Link-Local Addresses (LLA) for automatic address configuration on a single link, similar to IPv4's APIPA.

questions.text: Which protocol is used to automatically configure IPv6 addresses without a DHCP server?
questions.explanation: SLAAC (Stateless Address Autoconfiguration) allows devices to automatically configure IPv6 addresses without a DHCP server.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) in IPv6?
questions.explanation: NDP (Neighbor Discovery Protocol) is used for address resolution, router discovery, and neighbor unreachability detection in IPv6.
correctAnswers: Address resolution, router discovery, and neighbor unreachability detection
